did.abstract: Fifty-six 8x10 black and white photographs of people and scenes on New York City’s Lower East Side in 1931, just before the Jewish high holidays of Rosh Hashanah and Sukkot, shot by Samuel Zagat (1890-1964). Zagat, a Lithuanian-Jewish artist who immigrated to New York City as a child, is best known as a political cartoonist for Yiddish-language newspapers, in a career that spanned the years 1912 to 1964, the year of his death.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: Originally contained in an album. Probably separated from the Samuel Zagat Cartoons and Drawings Collection (Graphics 12).

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Samuel Zagat (1890-1964), a Lithuanian-Jewish artist who emigrated to New York City as a child, is best known for his work as a cartoonist: first for his popular comic strip, Gimpl Beinish, published in the Yiddish-language newspaper, Varhaytfrom 1912 to 1919, and later for his political cartoons published in the Jewish Daily Forwardfrom 1919 until his death in 1964. The Forward (where he also headed the art department and supervised the newspaper’s weekly rotogravure feature) also published his drawings of street life, court sessions, and theater. His cartoons and drawings also appeared in the New Masses, Jewish Morning Journal, and The Hat Worker(published by the Hat, Cap, and Millinery Workers Union).

list.item: Zagat, Ida R., ed. Jewish life on New York City's Lower East Side, 1912-1962.New York: Rogers Book Service, 1972.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Fifty-six 8x10 black and white photographs of people and scenes shot by Samuel Zagat on New York City’s Lower East Side in 1931, just before the Jewish high holidays of Rosh Hashanah and Sukkot. They include images of groups of people and individuals standing or sitting on a pier by a body of water (most likely the East River), many of them holding what are probably prayer books; they appear be waiting to perform the Tashlikh("casting off") (a Rosh Hashanah custom in which celebrants gather by a body of flowing water and turn their pockets inside-out, symbolically casting off their sins). There are also images of shoppers purchasing lulav and esrog (one a palm frond bound together with willow branches, the other a citrus fruit)–ritual items for Sukkot, from street vendors, as well as merchants offering or shoppers buying skullcaps, shoes, and dishes front outdoor stands. Most locations are not identified, but a few images are labeled "Hester and Essex Streets," or "Orchard Street." A number of the photographs in this collection were published in the Jewish Daily Forward.
